engagement_grid._comment: G1: Who was engaged and how

engagement_descriptions.people_who_use_drugs_other: People who use drugs, people in recovery, and their families are engaged on a regular basis by the Mansfield Police Department's Problem-Oriented Policing Unit (which will be referred to simply as the "POP Unit" or "POP program" or "Unit" for the remainder of this questionnaire). The preferred method of engagement is to always follow up in-person with the members of these specific populations in the location they are the most comfortable in, which is often their home. Third party resources (detox & treatment centers, pathways to therapy, etc.) are always offered to members of said populations during POP Unit interviews.

disparities_assessment.other_methods: The Mansfield Police Department's POP Unit has not identified any disparities in access to existing services & health outcomes for any of the categories highlighted in this question. This Unit, in its nearly 9 years of existence, is capable of making this statement with surety through its own personal experiences & observations after working closely with our partners in the fields of addiction & mental health.

behavioral_health_assessment._comment: G3: How behavioral health needs were assessed
behavioral_health_assessment.admin_data_sources: Call logs are searched on a daily basis, not only by the police officers assigned to the Unit, but also by part-time social services resource engagement personnel, the full-time civilian clinician assigned to the MPD. Secondly, Administrative Data Sources (such as CIMS) aid the Unit in identifying a Mansfield resident who (fatally or non-fatally) overdosed on opioids in another Massachusetts community.
behavioral_health_assessment.other_methods: Follow-up interviews are the most crucial fact-finding tool used by the Unit. Regional case conference with the Community Crisis Intervention Team or during a HART meeting.

planning.process: Our municipality conducted its own planning process.

Other (please specify):: It's difficult to check off full category boxes when responding to this question as the MPD POP Unit satisfies some of the pre-written response choices fully, but some only partially, so the "Other" box has been ticked off and will be explained below. Although the Unit, in and of itself, is not made up of peer support specialists, it does have a full-time clinician working alongside police officers for a true co-responder approach to policing. The clinician is qualified to offer the types of support described in this pre-written response but is more likely to refer individuals with OUD to one of the many treatment partners associated with the POP Unit, as would the police officers and civilians serving in this Unit.
